user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_destroy:
```c
void
MHD_pool_destroy (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  if (NULL == pool)
    return;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
  else
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    munmap (pool->memory,
            pool->size);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    VirtualFree (pool->memory,
                 0,
                 MEM_RELEASE);
#else
    abort ();
#endif
  free (pool);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_pool_destroy:
struct MemoryPool
{

  /**
   * Pointer to the pool's memory
   */
  uint8_t *memory;

  /**
   * Size of the pool.
   */
  size_t size;

  /**
   * Offset of the first unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t pos;

  /**
   * Offset of the byte after the last unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t end;

  /**
   * 'false' if pool was malloc'ed, 'true' if mmapped (VirtualAlloc'ed for W32).
   */
  bool is_mmap;
}
...
#define ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n) (((n)+(ALIGN_SIZE-1))/(ALIGN_SIZE)*(ALIGN_SIZE))
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY(pointer, size) (void)0
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:
- There are no GCC/MSVC/Clang extension keywords or constructs such as __attribute__, __declspec, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), inline assembly, or other vendor-specific language features.
- Preprocessor conditionals (#if defined(...), #elif, #else, #endif) and use of platform APIs (munmap, VirtualFree) are standard preprocessor and OS API usage, not compiler language extensions.
- Use of standard C types (uint8_t, size_t, bool) and ordinary macros (ROUND_TO_ALIGN, mhd_assert, _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY) are standard C constructs. (Note: identifiers beginning with an underscore and an uppercase letter are reserved by the C standard, but that is a naming/reserved-identifiers concern, not a compiler language-extension issue for MISRA C Rule 1.2.)
Given the above, there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions should not be used).
